courseTitle: Information Literacy for the Digital Age
courseDescription: Students require a comprehensive understanding of information literacy so they can become effective users of ideas and information and guide others in activities of knowledge use and creation. This course will provide an introduction to the process and methods of retrieving information using digital literacies. Students will learn to identify an information need, then locate, evaluate, and use appropriate resources while embedding the dispositions of academic integrity and ethical use. Topics include use of collaborative tools for development of information, including social media. The content focuses on implementing effective digital information literacy strategies situated in various content areas with the intent that these strategies can be incorporated into future professional and instructional practices.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of collaborative tools for development of information, including social media
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Guiding others in activities of knowledge use and creation
Collaborative development of information through digital tools
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Implementing effective digital information literacy strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Embedding academic integrity in information use
Incorporating digital literacy strategies into professional and instructional practices

courseTitle: STEM Education and Maker Spaces in Libraries
courseDescription: This course builds on current research and practice to strengthen candidates’ conceptual understanding of design-based STEM pedagogy. Through participation in activities and discussions, students will review concepts embedded within design-based, problem-based, project-based, and inquiry instruction and learning. This course will explore a synthesized overview of trends affecting STEM education and investigate makerspaces and making activities to support inquiry-driven, community engagement in information settings. Students will gain hands-on experience with digital and physical making toolkits and design maker experiences within library spaces.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of problem-based, project-based, and inquiry instruction and learning
Practical use of digital and physical making toolkits
Designing maker experiences within library spaces
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Reviewing and understanding embedded concepts within different teaching methodologies
Investigation and exploration of trends affecting STEM education
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and managing community engagement activities

courseDescription: Develops skills in preparing, evaluating, and presenting instructional materials and the use of those materials to promote higher-level thinking and enhance the learning environment. Includes elements of design, multimedia materials, and development of in-service activities. Hands-on practice in media production and dissemination.

Students will gain experience locating, evaluating, collecting, arranging, and disseminating content resources available as open educational resources to support learning and teaching. Issues surrounding open educational resources including copyright, licensing, access, and quality will be addressed. A primary focus will be on developing digital textbooks that may include websites, databases, current awareness experts, and digital field trips to support the delivery of instruction.
Technical and Digital Skills: Evaluating the quality of digital content
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the quality of open educational resources

courseDescription: This course provides social, cultural, and historical perspectives on libraries and librarianship. The purpose, functions and processes of libraries and information are explored.  Current types of libraries and information agencies are explored.  Legal, ethical, advocacy, and economic policies, trends and positions are addressed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of library systems and processes
Knowledge of different types of libraries and information agencies
Understanding of legal and ethical policies in libraries
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of library functions and purpose
Advocacy for libraries and information agencies
Understanding and discussing economic trends in libraries
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of library and information agency trends
Evaluation of library processes and functions
Problem solving in the context of library policies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and application of library and information agency policies
Leadership in advocacy and communication of library purposes
Organizing and managing library resources and processes

courseDescription: This course provides a historical perspective on books and libraries as social and cultural objects and spaces. Surveys the history of communication technologies from early history through current events and from stone tablets to electronic formats.

courseTitle: Preservation Management in Libraries and Archives
courseDescription: An introduction to the principles and practice of preservation with an emphasis on the management of preservation activities. Includes physical and intellectual preservation of records and media and the history, kinds of materials and treatments, techniques and technologies, and digitization and digital records. Issues of storage, security, and disaster prevention and response will also be addressed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Intellectual preservation of records and media
Understanding of preservation materials and treatments
Knowledge of preservation techniques and technologies
Digitization and management of digital records
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysing the types of materials for preservation
Identifying and resolving issues related to storage and security
Planning and implementing disaster prevention and response measures
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading disaster prevention and response measures

courseDescription: All communities create historical records, and recent decades have brought a growing critical awareness of how existing social hierarchies influence the creation and maintenance of historical archives. Community archive projects locate the power to preserve and shape history, heritage, and memory in communities themselves. Through readings, discussion, and analysis, this course will introduce students to a range of issues relating to grassroots community archives, archives of community organizations, and what happens when larger institutions partner with communities and community organizations to create and maintain archives.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of how larger institutions partner with communities to create and maintain archives
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Negotiation and mediation in community archival projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of social hierarchies in archival processes
Critical evaluation of community archival projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Creating and maintaining community partnerships with larger institutions

courseTitle: Research Methods in Library and Information Studies
courseDescription: This course will introduce students to theoretical and applied research design, methodologies, and evaluation of research in library and information science (LIS). The course will include a review of existing research, allowing students to evaluate and assess the potential value of literature and research findings through critical analysis. Basic qualitative and quantitative research protocols will be learned through this class.

Introduces the major theories and basic concepts of ethics. Historical and contemporary professional frameworks and positions will be analyzed in ethical contexts. Students will apply ethical principles to dilemmas and decision making in the information and library profession.
Technical and Digital Skills: Applying ethical frameworks to information and library profession
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing professional frameworks and positions in ethical contexts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Applying ethical principles in professional decision making

courseDescription: This course explores action research in a school library. Students will examine the value and characteristics of educational action research and apply these ideas toward the development of an action research project. Topics include the evaluation of published action research projects, community-based assessment, data collection and analysis, and the design and development of a project conducted in a school library setting.
Technical and Digital Skills: Evaluation of published action research projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying research principles to real-world problems

courseTitle: Web Archiving Theory, Practice, and Implications
courseDescription: An interdisciplinary introduction to web archiving fundamentals including web crawling, collection development and summarization including planning, analyzing, and sharing collections. Includes a review of ethical and legal issues, trustworthiness, preservation, security, and cultural impact of web archiving.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussing ethical and legal issues in web archiving
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Addressing security issues in web archiving
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and organizing web archiving projects
Leading discussions on ethical, legal, and cultural implications of web archiving

courseDescription: Students examine, evaluate, discuss, and use literature and related materials for children and young adolescents and explore strategies for introducing and using literature with children.
Technical and Digital Skills: Using related materials for children's literature
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating effectively with children and young adolescents
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating suitability of literature for different age groups
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and implementing strategies for literature introduction

courseTitle: Literature and Media for Young Adults
courseDescription: An exploration of the selection of literature and media for young adults (ages 12 - 18). Includes current trends and research in teens' social, physical and cultural development, teen interests and needs, and multiple literacies. Focus is on multiple formats, diverse learners, and strategies to promote reading for information, pleasure and lifelong learning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and application of current trends in young adult literature
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and addressing teen interests and needs
Promoting reading for pleasure and lifelong learning
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Research in teens' social, physical and cultural development
Strategizing to promote reading for information

courseDescription: Survey of trends and selection tools in literature and reading for adult library patrons including popular fiction and non-fiction genres in multiple formats and across life stages in adulthood.  Strategies will include reader’s advisory, book clubs, and other programming to meet the diverse needs and interests of adult readers.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Programming for diverse needs and interests

courseTitle: Reading, Evaluating, and Selecting Graphic Novels
courseDescription: This course explores the use, selection and evaluation of literature and media that use sequential art to tell stories in a visual format: comics, webcomics, graphic novels, and more. The course will include the history of the sequential art format; an exploration of reading through a variety of  graphics, text and media; and a survey of current and historical titles for all ages. Students will explore resources for selecting and evaluating materials in graphic format as well as specific applications for graphic materials in classrooms and libraries.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of graphic materials and media
Ability to navigate and utilize resources for selecting and evaluating graphic materials
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate and discuss the history and current trends of sequential art
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of literature and media using sequential art
Ability to analyze and interpret graphics and texts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of graphic resources for classroom and library applications
Curating and selecting appropriate graphic materials for different age groups

courseDescription: Explores storytelling for the purpose of informing, entertaining and/or educating in an information setting. This course introduces narrative structure and technique using a variety of different media. Storytelling strategies help students gain communication skills and practice. Students will explore the potential use of storytelling for a variety of age groups, from preschool through adults, and for special audiences.
Technical and Digital Skills: Techniques for storytelling via different media
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adapting storytelling for diverse age groups

courseTitle: User Centered Design in Library and Information
courseDescription: This course introduces current and future information professionals to user-centered design in library and information studies. Students learn how to conduct research with users, gather users' requirements, and develop intuitive, user-friendly interfaces (e.g., software, mobile applications). Theories and techniques for engaging users and designing user-centered interfaces are learned and applied.

Students will develop expertise in the delivery of in-person and online information literacy and research instruction in library and information contexts through an exploration of various information literacy models, standards, and theories. Students will gain practical experience in planning, implementing, and assessing library instruction and digital learning objects through a variety of delivery methods.
Technical and Digital Skills: Delivery of online information literacy and research instruction
Exploration of information literacy models, standards, and theories
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: In-person delivery of information literacy instruction
Communication of library instruction and digital learning objects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of various information literacy models, standards, and theories
Assessment of library instruction and digital learning objects
Adaptation of delivery methods to diverse needs

courseTitle: Methods and Strategies for the School Library
courseDescription: Participants will draw from research-based theory of pedagogical best practice to discuss, model and apply practical applications to content topics. Content focuses on strategies to implement effective classroom management for the library learning environment, engage library learners and assess their performance, and build collaborative relationships that integrates library and content instruction into practice.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying practical applications to content topics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Integrating library and content instruction into practice

courseDescription: The populations served by public libraries are varied and diverse, and they require resources that will address these diverse needs. Budgetary and political concerns, among other things, often restrict the ability of libraries to fulfill the needs of 'invisible populations,' or groups whose minority status is not readily or visually apparent, such as the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, intersex, asexual plus (LGBTQIA+) community. This course is designed to bring particular issues the LGBTQIA+ community may have in relation to public libraries to the forefront and provide students with the tools to address these issues in the field.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and addressing the needs of the LGBTQIA+ community
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Recognizing and addressing issues faced by 'invisible populations'
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Promoting inclusivity in library resources and services
Leadership in advocating for minority groups in public libraries

courseTitle: Knowledge Resources: Planning, Selecting & Managing Collections
courseDescription: Examines the concepts and issues related to the lifecycle of recorded knowledge and information including emerging technologies. Addresses fundamentals of planning, selecting, analyzing, managing, and developing collections and technology resources for diverse communities.

courseTitle: Internship in Libraries and Information Workplaces
courseDescription: Students will work in a library or related workplace, fully participating in the day-to-day operations including administrative tasks, instruction, and/or other programming and services.  Students taking this course for school library endorsement may have additional requirements/prerequisites.

Students will work in a school library setting, participating fully in the administrative tasks, collaborative planning with teaching peers, and preparation and delivery of instructional lessons. This course is for students who are already licensed teachers or who are seeking initial licensure in school librarianship.

An examination of the critical issues concerning the leadership and management of a library. Students will explore the issues involved in building library programs to include considerations of physical space, budgetary decisions, and personnel.

courseTitle: Library Media Services and the Curriculum
courseDescription: Emphasis is on library services/ programs and the curriculum of the school.  Includes techniques for curriculum design and development, information skills instruction, instructional partnerships, advocacy, implementation of an integrated library-media instructional program and public relations programs.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementation of an integrated library-media instructional program
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting curriculum to fit library-media instructional program
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementation of an integrated library-media instructional program

courseDescription: Describes the fundamentals whereby library materials are uniformly described and made available through recognized cataloging, processing, organizing and accessing of materials. In this course, students will develop the ability to apply and adapt the principles of classifying and cataloging, and will understand how these fundamental skills fit into the broader area of technical processing and how they support the principles of services in the library.
Technical and Digital Skills: Applying and adapting principles of cataloging
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting cataloging and classification principles to varying library materials
Understanding how cataloging supports library services
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding the broader area of technical processing

courseTitle: Theory and Management of Reference and Information Retrieval
courseDescription: Students will explore database structures, search algorithms, indexing principles, and user interfaces for information search and retrieval. Current issues in the evaluation, acquisitions and management of databases and other information resources will be addressed.  Includes advanced strategies for effective information search and educating and assisting users in search techniques and evaluation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Designing user interfaces for information search
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing current issues in database management and acquisition
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating user education and assistance in search techniques

courseDescription: This course provides thought-provoking background and practical suggestions for engaging with a diverse population. Participants explore their own assumptions about race, class, and culture and learn strategies for creating environments and an open dialog that are culturally inviting to all.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Facilitating open dialogues about race, class, and culture
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Exploring personal assumptions about race, class, and culture
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Creating an inclusive and welcoming library environment

courseTitle: Assessment and Evaluation in Library and Information Science
courseDescription: Students will explore assessment and evaluation related to library and information contexts with particular attention to historical and current theories and values, relevant standards, and current initiatives and measures. Students will design an evaluation of a current library service or resource that is connected to library goals and objectives with a presentation to effectively communicate data to various stakeholders.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of relevant standards and initiatives
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of library services and resources
Connection of assessments to goals and objectives
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Design of evaluations aligned with library goals
Implementation of current initiatives and measures

courseDescription: Reviews the advanced knowledge and competencies required for the senior administration level of all types of libraries and library systems. Competencies include budgeting and analysis, project management, human resources, and the development of library reporting and advocacy materials.

Cataloging and metadata principles introduced in LIBS 677 are further developed and applied in this course.  Students will apply principles of bibliographic description, subject analysis, and classification to a variety of formats including multimedia, serials, and online resources. The course will address systems, technology and trends in cataloging and metadata environments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Classification of various formats including multimedia, serials, and online resources
Understanding of systems, technology and trends in cataloging and metadata environments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of various formats including multimedia, serials, and online resources
Identification and analysis of trends in cataloging and metadata environments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of various formats including multimedia, serials, and online resources
Adaptation to changing technology and trends in cataloging and metadata environments

courseDescription: Academic libraries are dynamic organizations, working to meet the needs of their users and stakeholders while supporting parent higher education institutions. This course examines the functions of the academic library within the higher education environment. A wide variety of topics are covered in this survey of the field, including a focus on the historical background, current trends, and future directions in academic librarianship.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of current trends in academic librarianship
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of library functions within higher education
Assessment of future directions in academic librarianship

courseDescription: Students will gain an understanding of public libraries in the United States and their role within their communities. Topics covered include a historical background of public libraries, overviews of current trends, and future directions in public libraries. This course also explores public services, the roles and expectations of public librarianship as a career.

courseTitle: Seminar in Archives and Special Collections
courseDescription: An introduction to the nature of archives and special collections. The course explores the history of special collections, archives, records, and cultural memory. Aspects of the profession including ethics, values, financial and legal responsibilities are included. Students will be introduced to the basic knowledge, tools, methods and practices associated with archival work.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of special collections and records
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding of the nature of archives and special collections
Understanding of the history of special collections, archives, records, and cultural memory
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of professional ethics and values in archival work
Knowledge of financial and legal responsibilities in archival work

courseTitle: Seminar in Social Justice in Library and Information Work
courseDescription: In this seminar course, students will explore current social justice issues through an activist framework.  Historical and contemporary frameworks, positions and initiatives related to the library profession will be considered. The course will examine professional structures, documents, emerging frameworks and social actions as they relate to specific topics of social justice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching historical and contemporary social justice issues
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in an activist framework
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of historical and contemporary frameworks
Assessing initiatives related to the library profession
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on social justice issues
Organizing information related to social justice topics

courseTitle: Topics in Library and Information Studies
courseDescription: This course provides opportunities for graduate students to explore current topics, trends and issues related to libraries and information studies.
This course is an independent study of special topics in Library Science.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication with various age groups and demographics
